required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Immunogenicity of Seasonal Influenza by Delivery Directly to Ileum
clinical_study.official_title: An Open Label Phase I Substudy to Evaluate the Safety and Ability to Enhance Immunogenicity of VXA-A1.1 by Delivery Directly to the Ileum Using the InteliSite Companion Capsule in Healthy Adult Males

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: the purpose of the study is to determine the safety and tolerability of VXA-A1.1, an adjuvanted adenoviral based influenza vaccine, when delivery is targeted to the ileum, using a radio controlled capsule. The secondary objective is to evaluate the immune response (cellular and humoral) of two doses of VXA-A1.1 oral vaccine.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.description: Frequency and magnitude of adverse events

secondary_outcome.description: Antibody and T cell responses to HA

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Able and willing to complete informed consent
- Healthy, as established by medical history, physical exam, and laboratory assessments
- Has normal bowel movements
- Willing to abstain from caffeine and xanthine containing substances for 24 hours before procedure until after discharge
Exclusion Criteria:
- Not able to donate up to 550 ml of blood over several months
- Exposure to an investigational drug or vaccine 8 weeks prior to study
- Abnormal ECG findings
- History of irritable bowl or any other inflammatory gastrointestinal disorder
- Any individual with increased risk for bowl obstruction
- Radiation exposure above target values 50 mSv within the past 30 days or a cumulative dose above 150 mSV in the past 12 months
- History of substance abuse
- Subject unwilling to use an approved method of contraception during study and for 2 months after study
- Positive for HCV, HIV, or HBV
- Presence of implantable device that is sensitive to radio frequencies ( e.g. pacemakers)
- History of autoimmune disorder, or an immunosuppressive disorder
- Stool sample with occult blood at baseline
- Any other medical, psychiatric, social condition, or occupation, in the judgement of the investigator is a contraindication to the compliance of the protocol or informed consent
